definitions.definition: of high quality or an acceptable standard

examples.text: a good book
good food
The piano was in **really good** condition.
Your work is just **not good enough**.
The results were **pretty good**.
Sorry, my English is not very good.
They've done a reasonably **good job**.
Keep up the **good work**!
It's a **good way** to make friends.
The sound and picture are both of **good quality**.
Things are **looking good** at the moment.
You'll never marry her—she's much **too good for** you.
This essay really is very good.
The food was surprisingly good.
I think that make of car's pretty good.
Her school report was much better this year.
He doesn't seem to have a very good diet.
a really good film
Citrus fruits are a good source of vitamin C.
Why ruin a perfectly good story?
You've done a pretty good job.
Get yourself a haircut and a good suit before the interview.
She gives a good performance as the innocent young woman.

definitions.definition: pleasant; that you enjoy or want
definitions.sensetop: it is good to do something

examples.text: Did you have a **good time** in London?
This is very **good news**.
Let's hope we have good weather tomorrow.
It's good to see you again.
examples.contextForm: it is good to do something

examples.text: There are loads of **good things** about working here.
We are still friends, though, which is good.
It'd be a good place to go on holiday, but not to live in.
It would be good if he moved to London.
In good weather, they sometimes went riding.
If the weather's good, we can take a picnic.
‘What was the weather like on your holiday?’ ‘Good.’

definitions.definition: sensible, logical or strongly supporting what is being discussed

examples.text: Thank you, **good question**.
Yes, that's a **good point**.
I have **good reason** to be suspicious.
What a **good idea**!
This is a **good example** of what I mean.
You raised several good points in your email.
You'll have to think of a better excuse than that!
That's a really good idea.
My father once gave me some good advice.
‘But where are we going to stay?’ ‘That's a very good question.’
‘They won't be able to find the way without a map.’ ‘ Good point.’

definitions.definition: showing or getting approval or respect

examples.text: The play had good reviews.
The hotel has a good reputation.
He comes from a good family.
Initial reactions to the proposal have been good so far.
We got a pretty good response from our viewers about the programme.
The school has an extremely good reputation.

definitions.definition: able to do something well
definitions.sensetop: good at somethinggood at doing something

examples.text: a **good player**
a good actor/cook
to be good at languages/your job
Nick has always been good at finding cheap flights.
She's a really good actor.
I'm not really a very good cook.
She's getting quite good at reading now.
Are you any good at languages?

definitions.definition: able to use something or deal with people well

examples.text: She's good with her hands *(= able to make things, etc.)*.
He's very good with children.
She's good with figures.

definitions.definition: morally right; behaving in a way that is morally right

examples.text: She has tried to lead a **good life**.
I took Sarah's children to school so I've done my **good deed** for the day.
Giving her that money was a good thing to do.
He is a very good man.
She prayed that God would make her a better person.

definitions.definition: following strictly a set of rules or principles

examples.text: It is **good practice** to supply a written report to the buyer.
She was a good Catholic girl.

definitions.definition: willing to help; kind to other people
definitions.sensetop: good to somebodygood of somebodygood of somebody to do somethinggood about something

examples.text: You've always been such a **good friend**.
He was very good to me when I was ill.
She looked into it for me, which was very good of her.
It was very good of you to come.
examples.contextForm: good of somebody to do something

examples.text: I had to take a week off work but my colleagues were very good about it.

definitions.definition: behaving well or politely

examples.text: You can stay up late if you're good.
Get dressed now, there's a good girl.
‘That's a good dog,’ I said, patting its head.
I want you all to be good while I'm out of the room.
She's usually quite good in class.

definitions.definition: healthy or strong

examples.text: Can you speak into my good ear?
I don't **feel **too **good** today.
‘How are you?’ ‘I'm good.’ *(= used as a general reply to a greeting)*

definitions.definition: having a useful or helpful effect on somebody/something
definitions.sensetop: good for somebody/somethingit is good for somebody/something to do something

examples.text: Living so close to a chemicals factory can't be good.
Too much sun isn't good for you.
Vegetables are good for you.
policies that are **good for business**
The deal will be **good for the country** as a whole.
It's probably good for you to get some criticism now and then.
examples.contextForm: it is good for somebody/something to do something

examples.text: Shut your mouth, **if you know what's good for you** *(= used as a threat)*.

definitions.definition: suitable or appropriate
definitions.sensetop: good for something/to do somethinggood for somebody

examples.text: Now is a **good time** to buy a house.
Do you really think this is a **good use** of your time?
Students are not allowed to miss classes without **good reason**.
She would be good for the job.
Can we change our meeting? Monday isn't good *(= convenient)* for me.
This is **as good a** place **as any** to spend the night.

definitions.definition: used in speaking to show that you approve of or are pleased about something that has been said or done, or to show that you want to move on to a new topic of conversation

examples.text: ‘Dinner's ready.’ ‘Good—I'm starving.’
‘I got the job.’ ‘Oh, good.’
Good, I think we've come to a decision.

definitions.definition: used as a form of praise

examples.text: Good old Jack!
‘I've ordered some drinks.’ ‘Good man!’

definitions.definition: used in exclamations

examples.text: Good heavens!
Good God!

definitions.definition: great in number, amount or degree

examples.text: a good number of people
The kitchen is a good size.
We spent a good while *(= quite a long time)* looking for the house.
He devoted **a good deal of** *(= a lot of)* attention to the problem.
There's **a good chance** *(= it is likely)* that I won't be here next year.

definitions.definition: not less than; rather more than

examples.text: We waited for a good hour.
It's a good three miles to the station.

definitions.definition: done to a high level or a great degree; complete

examples.text: We had a good laugh about it afterwards.
You'll feel better after a good sleep.

definitions.definition: funny or clever

examples.text: a good story/joke
That's a good one!

definitions.definition: having enough energy, health, strength, etc. to last for a particular length of time or distance

examples.text: You're good for *(= you will live)* a few years yet.

definitions.definition: acceptable for something

examples.text: The ticket is good for three months.

definitions.definition: likely to provide something

examples.text: He's always good for a laugh.
Bobby should be good for a few drinks.

definitions.definition: very nearly

examples.text: The matter is as good as settled.
He as good as called me a coward *(= suggested that I was a  without actually using the word ‘coward’).
She’s as good as won.

definitions.definition: used when you are saying that a situation is not going to get any better
(of a thing) to be prepared and ready for use; (of a person) to be prepared and ready to do something

examples.text: By tomorrow afternoon the document will be good to go.
I’ve spent several months training for this race so now I’m good to go.

definitions.definition: completely

examples.text: I won't go until I'm good and ready.

definitions.definition: several

examples.text: There are still a good few empty seats.

definitions.definition: used to praise somebody for doing something well

examples.text: ‘I passed first time.’ ‘Good for you!’

definitions.definition: a lot of somebody/something

examples.text: There were a good many people there.

wordOrigin: Old English gōd, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch goed and German gut.
